abstract.p: Saul D Raw letter says generations of immigrants learned English through classroom immersion, not bilingual teaching; adds that most young children have ability to learn languages easily, and there is no reason why native Spanish-speakers should not be able to do likewise

block.p: Re ''Increase in Test Scores Counters Dire Forecasts for Bilingual Ban'' (front page, Aug. 20), on the improvement in scores on reading and other subjects by students in California two years after the state voted to end bilingual education:

Re ''Increase in Test Scores Counters Dire Forecasts for Bilingual Ban'' (front page, Aug. 20), on the improvement in scores on reading and other subjects by students in California two years after the state voted to end bilingual education:

Generations of non-English-speaking students, including my mother and my aunt, learned English by being immersed in it in the classroom. Students with other linguistic backgrounds are successfully doing the same thing today.

Most young children have the ability to learn languages easily, and there is no good reason why native Spanish-speaking students should not be able to do likewise. Problems of poverty and lack of preparation for learning are things that must be faced with or without bilingual education.
